author: By Captain Greybeard
title: Luxury line Crystal Cruises announces incredible expansion plans which astound the industry
text:
Ultra-luxury line Crystal Cruises has won more “World’s Best” awards for its two ships than anyone else in travel.
Now the company is to embark on an ambitious multi-billion dollar expansion that will bring new ocean-going vessels, a luxury yacht, river cruises and a private jet.
The new ocean ships will each be about 100,000 tons and designed to carry 1,000 passengers and 1,000 crew – providing unrivalled ratios of space and staff per guest.
The nearest competitors in the luxury market offer about 65 tons of space per guest, while the figure for mainstream ships is 40 or less.
The smallest suites on board will be 400 square metres.
The ships will have one deck devoted to 48 apartments available for sale as permanent residences and owners will have their own private restaurant and reception area.
Below the top deck guest suites will be a minimum of 400 square feet, almost double the size of most other luxury vessels. Cruises are all-inclusive with no charges for drinks or speciality restaurants.
The first Crystal Exclusive Class ship is scheduled to enter service in late 2018.
Crystal’s expansion begins later this year with the launch of a 672-passenger yacht complete with a range of water toys that includes jet skis, kayaks and even a two-man submarine.
The maiden voyage of Crystal Esprit will be a Christmas cruise in The Seychelles – and passengers will end their holiday by flying to New Year’s Eve celebrations at the Taj Hotel, Dubai.
Spring 2017 sees the arrival of Crystal River Cruises aboard two purpose-built ships with all-suite accommodation.
Later in 2017, Crystal will soar to new heights with the arrival of Crystal Luxury Air, offering extravagant round-the-world trips on a sumptuously-appointed Boeing 787 Dreamliner.
The planes are normally configured to carry up to 300 passengers – this one will be fitted with just 60 fully-reclining lie-flat seat-beds.
Crystal, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this year, was originally owned by a Japanese shipping company.
It was bought this year by financiers and resort operator Genting Hong Kong.
President and CEO Edie Rodriguez has been promising developments ever since she was appointed in October 2013.
When she revealed the company’s news on board Crystal Serenity this week, its scope and ambition went way beyond the expectations of the entire travel industry.
